The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 allows the Secretary to take legal action to recover backpay, interest, benefits, and damages for employees. Any recovered sums are held in a special account and paid directly to affected employees. Unpaid sums after 3 years are credited to the Secretary of Labor's appropriations account. The Secretary of Labor can take legal action to recover back pay, interest, benefits, and compensation for employees under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The district courts have jurisdiction over such actions. There is a 2-year limitations period for bringing an action under this section. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act is amended to limit private actions while the Secretary of Labor is pursuing enforcement actions. If the Secretary initiates proceedings, individual employees cannot bring actions during the proceedings. ``SEC. 11. POSTING OF NOTICES; PENALTIES. Each employer must post a notice with key provisions of this chapter and filing complaint information. Willful violation results in a fine of up to $500 per offense.`` ``SEC. 12. RIGHTS AND REMEDIES NOT SUBJECT TO WAIVER. The rights and remedies provided under this Act may not be waived, deferred, or lost except through specific agreements negotiated by authorized parties. SEC. 13. INFORMATION REGARDING BENEFITS AND SERVICES AVAILABLE TO WORKERS.`` The Secretary of Labor must maintain a guide of benefits and services for affected employees, including unemployment compensation, trade adjustment assistance, COBRA benefits, and access to training under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The guide will be available on the Department of Labor's website and will detail eligibility requirements and how to obtain these benefits. Upon receiving notice from an employer, the Secretary will provide the guide. Additionally, in cases of a terrorist attack causing notification delays, the employer is excused from providing notice as per the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act. No notice is required under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act if a plant closing or mass layoff is due to a terrorist attack on the United States. Extension of COBRA benefits for certain individuals certified as TAA eligible. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 include a special rule for qualified TAA eligible employees regarding qualifying events and the application of certain clauses. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 provide a special rule for qualified TAA eligible employees, defining them as covered employees affected by a qualifying event certified by the Secretary of Labor under the Trade Act of 1974. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 establish criteria for qualified TAA eligible employees, including age and years of service requirements. Conforming amendments are also made to the Act. Effective date for these amendments is set for plan years starting on or after January 1. The amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 set criteria for qualified TAA eligible employees, with an effective date for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2008. Special rules apply for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements. The amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 establish criteria for qualified TAA eligible employees, with an effective date of July 1, 2008, or 3 years after the enactment of this Act. The provisions of the Act and its amendments will take effect on the date of enactment.
